topic.title: KopyKate Torrent Upload Tutorial
topic.body:
**KopyKate Torrent Upload Tutorial**
- Step 1: Choose an .mp4 video. Only mp4's will work. Make sure the video codec is [h.264] and the audio codec is [aac]!
- Step 2: Add the video to the uploader, fill in the title and descriptions. Hotlink an image thumbnail if desired. 
- Step 3: Before you close the tab, add the magnet link (which is automatically filled) into your WebTorrent.Desktop client. (Download link: https://www.webtorrent.io/desktop). Don't close the tab until you have added the magnet link to the client, otherwise your torrent will disappear!
- Step 4: Once the video is loaded into the client, you may now click 'Add video', and close the tab. The video will play so long as WebTorrent.Desktop is running and your computer is turned on!

topic.title: Rick Astley - Never Gonna Give You Up
Kopykate Webseed Upload Tutorial
topic.body:
**Kopykate Webseed Upload Tutorial**
- Note: Webseeds are not to be relied upon entirely! It's only to provide a backup for torrents that are lacking in peers.
- Step 1: Add your desired .mp4 video to Dropbox. Only mp4's will work. Make sure the video codec is [h.264] and the audio codec is [aac]!
- Step 2: Copy the shared link to this video into a text editor.
- Step 3: Remove the following text at the end of the url '?dl=0'
- Step 4: Change 'www.dropbox.com' to 'dl.dropboxusercontent.com'
- Step 5: Add your desired .mp4 video to your WebTorrent.Desktop client (download link: https://www.webtorrent.io/desktop)
- Step 6: Once the torrent is loaded, right click it and copy the magnet link.
- Step 7: Paste the magnet link into the text editor. Add the following text at the end of this link: '&ws='
- Step 8: Add your modified dropbox link to the end of the '&ws=' string.
- Step 9: Copy the entire modified magnet link and paste it into the player at https://instant.io/
- Step 10: Once instant.io has loaded the torrent, you should see 2 Peers.
- Step 11: Download the .torrent file [Download .torrent]
- Step 12: Upload the .torrent file into your Dropbox, in the same folder where your desired .mp4 is located.
- Step 13: Copy the link to this .torrent file, and paste it into the text editor.
- Step 14: Repeat Step 3 and Step 4.
- Step 15: This modified link to your .torrent Dropbox file can now be pasted in place of magnet links when adding new videos to KopyKate. It will play without the need for 24/7 seeding!
- Note: This will work on any cloud/web server that has CORS (cross-origin resource sharing) enabled!

5_1PvAednzaMJiuMz1SD5wF3m3Hx7SK75zHv.body:
Hey. :)
I think as far as I remember, TOR browser may have cancelled WebRTC connections altogether, so it won't work at all using Tor.

The only way to truly stay safe when torrenting is to use a VPN. Then again, the chances of getting caught, or even getting a slap on the wrist, are so low . . I'd probably be more worried about a polar bear coming out of my closet.

So if you're serious about safety, invest in a VPN. If not, then stream ahead and don't worry - everybody pirates these days, it's impossible not to. ;)

8_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_3_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I noticed dropbox has killed what I was doing for webseeding, so I was trying to figure out a new method. Hopefully this works for you guys. I'm going through Peerify by Btorrent. Seems to work great. I also moved the other videos over as well. I've noticed it gives higher speeds than dropbox did too, so that's a plus. Though I'm wondering if they might remove the videos after some time, I really don't know. So I'll keep an eye out and see how it goes.

I'd just be careful about uploading too many videos to Peerify. There's apparently a 200mb limit .. the owner merely did it as an experiment to show what can be accomplished with Webtorrent, not for it to become a filesharing cloud .. lol

I did ask him at one point if he had the source code for Peerify.. but he said to me that it will remain closed source.

It shouldn't be hard to accomplish in principle though. All you need is a script that uploads files to your VPS and then creates a .torrent file that automatically adds the uploaded .mp4 as a webseed. Cross-origin resource sharing would have to be enabled.

I'm running a VPS myself for my webseeds, but I only have a 200gb limit right now. It's not a permanent solution to lack of seeds - we'll just have to hope that more people take interest in the project for it to become an uncensored YouTube alternative.

> [kaffie](#comment_5_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Thanks for the heads up. I'm still trying to find a good solution for people to jump on and have low investment. I've been trying to figure out how to mirror Bitchute videos, but it seems without CORS enabled there's not much we can do. There doesn't seem to be a clean solution, unfortunately. Perhaps we could make ZeroNet our webseed? Would that be possible? Upload the video as an optional file, and then generate the torrent for it and have users help spread the webseed if they need it, and otherwise download from peers.
> As I mentioned, I unfortunately don't have a dedicated server of any kind that I can play around with, and if possible I'd like to work on a free solution to get as many people involved as possible. I'm curious what you mean by 'a 200mb limit'. You mean I'd just be blocked from uploading more? Or that the older files would be deleted? Either way, relying on it is probably a bad idea. But it's useful for people who want to upload a video or two.

I think my main concern is what Diego would think about people using it to upload on KopyKate, not so much the data limit .. haha. He would probably not be very happy about it .. and e-mail me or something.

Obviously, the only way to get KopyKate popular is to share the link and spread the word (WWW.KopyKate.GA). And thus, the more people are viewing, the more seeding gets done .. so it's a matter of getting a constant stream of viewers in order to sustain the torrents on the internet, without even having to seed them from the Desktop client.

You can actually Upload videos using a zeronet Proxy, so downloading the Zeronet client to participate is no longer necessary. It's only a matter of remembering the key to your Masterseed that is automatically generated each time you visit the site (store it on a USB drive), creating a ZeroID .. and then using it as normal.  I guess I'd have to create lots of video tutorials on that  , too ..... I guess I'll stop procrastinating and do it this weekend.

Using ZeroNet to store the videos may work in principle, but in practice that means that the site would take ages to load, because everyone who wants to seed the site would have to download each individual video stores on the entire site .. and at one point it would probably take years to load it. ;)

> [kaffie](#comment_6_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Yeah, I guess that makes sense haha. I sent a message over to the bitchute guys to see if they'll add CORS support to their webseeds. They have restricted uploads at the moment, but I explained how being able to share the content would be good as a whole. Perhaps we can get more cross-over content that way.
> 
> The problem is that this will always remain an issue for new videos. I doubt that every single video always has two people watching it. Really what needs to happen is a sort of federated data storage for these video sharing platforms. Something like what usenet does.
> 
> Well it'd be optional files. The only people who'd have to download them would be the people trying to watch the video. Alternatively I saw ZeroMux doing a lot of work with video streaming. Perhaps something like that could be tied in?

Ideally, the best course of action would be to have a sort of hybrid system in which everything works together in harmony, so I suppose you are right. Kinda like we have right now, but more user-friendly.. lol

Thus, a site that would temporarily web-seed new videos until they get enough seeders would be ideal!

25_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body:
> [anim76](#comment_1_14aG268HqAHbykUN9h1kRzaGZHfrMtV33R): Are we expected to allow scripts from a 3d party site, kittyseedbox, in order to use the site? -_-

Nope. You can always seed your torrents from the WebTorrent.Desktop client.

Webseeding is only for those who don't want to or can't seed e.g. Can't leave computer running 24/7, etc.
The site is viewable in ZeroNet. Kittyseedbox is a ZeroNet proxy for those who want to try the site without downloading ZeroNet client. It's also a temporary seedbox. ;)

> [anim76](#comment_2_14aG268HqAHbykUN9h1kRzaGZHfrMtV33R): I sat here 5min, still won't load (firefox standard)

Are you blocking 3rd party scripts?

Just use the Alternate Player in a separate tab if for whatever reason it won't load. Instant.io is a torrent client. The player on this site is also technically just a torrent client, except it only works on Firefox because it's loaded within an iFrame.

Of course, if that won't work either, then there's gotta be something in your browser settings that's blocking the requests. I'd need more info e.g. Operating system, Browser version, are you behind a firewall on a college campus, etc. in order to work on a fix, that is .. assuming that we're talking about a bug, and not just user-specific settings.

> [anim76](#comment_3_14aG268HqAHbykUN9h1kRzaGZHfrMtV33R): That prompted me to download the torrent. The problem was that I needed webtorrent installed, after that, vids load fine. Please clarify to users that it is required, try to find a way to make it work w/o requiring them to install sftwre as well.

Streaming should work on the browser without the need of additional software.

3_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk.body:
Remember that webTorrent.desktop needs to be open for this to work, with the torrent you uploaded.

Uploading to kopykate is like uploading to Pirate Bay. If you close your torrent client, videos won't work, because the videos aren't stored on a server.

Seems to me like the user must have a basic understanding of torrenting in order to use the uploader correctly .. but I think that's not too much to ask for. If you want freedom and an uncensored media platform, you'll need to be willing to make a bit of effort. Otherwise, there's always YouTube.

> [darvy](#comment_6_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk): Thanks for your guys help but I'll stick with centralized video hosting. Things like WebTorrent, Dropbox and Instant.io need integrated into Kopy Kate or something like them needs integrated into Kopy Kate. There are just to many steps needed to get videos to play right, that's a big turn off for me. Kopy Kate needs to be more like ZeroMusic but for videos instead of mp3's, where people can just upload videos directly to Kopy Kate.

ZeroMusic isn't centralized, it's still decentralized.

However, the way ZeroMusic works is you have music files stored inside the very site itself. Every one who loads the site will also have to download every single .mp3 file that is stored in it.

Could you imagine if you had to download every single YouTube video in existence, before you could watch YouTube? In the early days of the site, it may have taken a few hours .. but over the years, people have uploaded zillions of gigabites worth of video. It would probably take a lifetime to download all that content with an average internet speed, unless you introduce centralization.. but centralization means weakness, the risk of getting DMCA raids, etc.

I think the same thing will eventually happen to any ZeroNet site that uses this method. However, the only reason it works well at the moment is because ZeroNet is not popular enough and not enough data has been uploaded to these sites.

This site only stores magnet links, and magnet links only take up a few bytes of data .. and even so it will eventually have to split up its load if it becomes big enough. If someone wants to watch a video, they only stream the video they want to watch by pointing their torrent clients at a magnet address.

11_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body:
> [xialvjun](#comment_1_1Q2C6xA6oZPUYoaviepNeJEcCeM8UoMKrt): Why can not it play?  The <video> element's src is unknown...

It won't play on Chrome.

ZeroNet uses iFrames to render pages and videos won't stream inside of iFrames when using Chrome.

Fortunately, there's the Alternate Player button that can take you out of the iFrame. Cheers!

34_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body: I love my new PC. I can encode a 45 min TV show from MKV to Mp4 in under 5-6 minutes.. at 480p :)

Seriously though, I can't friggen STAND hannah, as a character. Everything about her attitude just raises the hairs behind my neck. I would avoided someone like that in high school like the plague. Probably the only character I really like is Clay. 

Amazing storytelling, acting and directing though. If you can get me to watch a TV show and stick to it, and torrent it .. you're doing a good job. Take it as a compliment. ;)

33_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_12_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Really good show. Definitely worth watching.

Yeh. There's something about the show that really reinforces how I already feel about the 21st century.

For one, I cannot stand our social media/iPhone culture. It's cancer. Take me back to the 90s when friends knocked on each other's doors uninvited and called each other on the landline, and when getting back with old friends from overseas required you to purchase a telephone scratch card or go to a phone center or something.

Hell - even my parents use social media and smartphones more than I do. I feel like an outsider.

35_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body: I'll see if I can find a better source for a proper encode. WEBRIPS are notorious for having problems with framerates. This one in particular has a problem with the frame refresh rate, which causes visible flickering. Pretty unusual.

> [kopyjane](#comment_20_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): I'll see if I can find a better source for a proper encode. WEBRIPS are notorious for having problems with framerates. This one in particular has a problem with the frame refresh rate, which causes visible flickering. Pretty unusual.

Ah, never mind. Turns out, the video tearing was a problem on my side.. It seems to have gone away after updating my NVIDIA drivers on Ubuntu.

1_1Atf4FiikU2m9P6Fy73KoCuueXy7cfoURY.body:
BitTorrent links don't work on the WebTorrent script. They're two different protocols.. 

I think some people won't get it even if you explain it to them over and over again, it makes me wonder how they even managed to install ZeroNet. Then again, if one is patient and willing to learn, uploading becomes as easy as two or three clicks, really.

I had to re-locate my ZeroNet Proxy server to a different location, as the owner of the VPS is moving his servers to New Zealand .. so I need to re-load the webseeds one by one again (fucking pain in the ass though). All videos should be playing pretty soon again.

 Lots more to come too. Uploading will be faster because I can just drag and drop the files, instead of establishing a remote connection. ;)

I'm gonna soon be working on an Automatic WebSeeder. This should allow users to web-seed small videos by uploading them to a webserver and generating a .torrent file link. The videos will then be deleted after 7 days or so, so it's up to the user to get them seeding by then .. otherwise, it would eventually become a target for DMCA strikes.

I know how Peerify works now, I just need to have a go at it and get the code right, set it up on my own server.

1_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_20_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Weirdly the video works fine in instant.io and in my webtorrent desktop, but on KopyKate it gives issues. Weird. As usual though, it works fine once I personally start seeding the vid. I'll try to help seed it. A+ for original content :)

It actually works after a couple of re-freshes.. but it takes a while to load either way. Pretty strange.. I haven't experienced this problem with Dropbox yet. Maybe there's some bandwidth throttling going on ?

Seems like Instant.io just has a longer waiting/timeout period.

Ah, I think I've found the problem.

** magnet:?xt=urn:btih:7c46cca34d2395159ee9532eba8e6c37da4d642c&dn=SSLbuild.mp4&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Fexplodie.org%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.coppersurfer.tk%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.leechers-paradise.org%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openbittorrent.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.opentrackr.org%3A1337&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Fzer0day.ch%3A1337&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.btorrent.xyz&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.fastcast.nz&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openwebtorrent.com&ws= **

The magnet link of this torrent file (you can retrieve it on Instant.io by right-clicking on Magnet link and copying). 

It's missing the link to the .mp4 at the end, but it has the &ws= string.. which means the script will probably struggle to find the .mp4 file at the beginning as it tries to guess where it is.

Here's an example of a magnet link of a video I uploaded to dropbox:

** magnet:?xt=urn:btih:aec8725e8281bad07587db37398533a722d5860f&dn=KATYPERRY_TEENAGEDREAM.mp4&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Fexodus.desync.com%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.coppersurfer.tk%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.internetwarriors.net%3A1337&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.leechers-paradise.org%3A6969&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openbittorrent.com%3A80&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.btorrent.xyz&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.fastcast.nz&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openwebtorrent.com&ws=https%3A%2F%2Fdl.dropboxusercontent.com%2Fs%2Fg28ac2g74pyjkle%2FKATYPERRY_TEENAGEDREAM.mp4 **
Tutorial videos are back up now, anyway. Happy webseeding. ;)

> [kaffie](#comment_21_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Well I'm seeding the video now. So it should work 100% of the time haha.
> 
> Sweet. Gonna go dl and seed.

Seeding would be well-appreciated, even for webseeds. :)

I'm essentially running a seedbox on my home network now, since the VPS is undergoing maintenance .. and my router tends to give up on me at times. Need a new router, as well as a usb Ethernet adapter, since the ethernet connection of this PC is kinda screwed.. very sensitive. It's so loose that even the vibration of your footsteps will cause it to play up.

> [kaffie](#comment_22_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Ah, I could tell the videos aren't going at the 10mb/s they used to haha. I certainly can't seed 24/7, only when my laptop is on (more or less all day). But the tutorial vids are important :P. And this? Well this is just good content haha. We need more than just pirated movies and youtube rips on here lol.
> Oh, also, go contact the bitchute guy. He's open to seeding vids, as he does it for his site based on the same tech, and he's recently been trying to open it up so other sites can use his webseeds. If we can get that working, that's a lot of content able to be mirrored, as well as a potential host for people to upload vids to for webseeding. ray@bitchute.com is his email.

Of course, one issue I haven't mentioned yet is that WebTorrent desktop can only really seed up to 10 videos at a time, until it starts to cause CPU overload issues. The issue hasn't been fixed yet, but may eventually..

It's best just to let it run at night-time.. or whenever the computer isn't used, especially if you're using your PC for gaming or video encoding or something. A little seeding is better than none. If everyone did a bit of seeding then torrents would be on 24/7, that's the point I guess..

WebTorrent was really meant for spontaneous seeding .. users seeding as they watch videos .. but for that you need a lot of viewers of course. In the meantime, I guess web-seeds will do.. until we get more viewers. As I said, I'll be creating a Peerify alternative soon.. and link it with this site.

> [kaffie](#comment_23_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Yeah, I actually ran into that issue when seeding a bunch of stuff for ZeroTube. It's real unfortunate and is the biggest hurdle of getting webtorrent to the masses.
> 
> Yeah, you'd need a lot of viewers to do it live. I was actually wondering if it might just be best to make a webtorrent video site as an app so that you can manage the DLs/seeds, and perhaps just use regular torrents instead. That'd fix the issues. But of course it's not on the web.

http://kopykate.ga/ should be available for standard web viewing, even on mobile. (will only work on android, though!)

The whole point of using ZeroNet to store magnet link databases is to protect them from DMCA strikes. 

The reason why The Pirate Bay got shut down multiple times, is because they were essentially a Yellow Pages for magnet links. They never hosted copyrighted content on their servers, but they enabled users to search and find copyrighted material.. so even if you lead other people to copyrighted material, it's the same penalty as hosting it.

I want KopyKate to be an uncensorable alternative to YouTube. There's a lot of work to do, having said that .. but it will be worth it when it's ready!

2_19yRyR57LxFjbzieSEhvyvhe4heSo7KrLa.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_30_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Seems to work fine. Instant.io works better, gives 2 peers and I get up to 3MB/s. KopyKate leads to a slower dl at ~1MB/s and less, and then cuts out after a few seconds for some reason. No idea why that is though. Entirely watchable on instant.io and webtorrent desktop. And as usual, once I start seeding with webtorrent desktop, the kopykate vid works fine. Hmm. Either way, good upload IMO.

Maybe instant.io has a more updated Webtorrent.js version .. I'll have to check and see. Most likely to be the case..

Anywhoo .. great upload!

37_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body:
Fucking classic. Why do good shows never get the hype they need?

Actually, I retract what I said - I'm glad they didn't ruin it with hype! This is my show .. nobody else's ... :D
